content.description: The route starts on a crimpy face then proceeds into a wide crack.
content.protection: Small cams and nuts are required to protect the lower section.  A couple large cams (4 - 5) will be needed for the upper crack section.
content.location:
Follow the large crack on the south-facing face.  Rappel to the bottom of the cliff to start the route.

Getting off: top off and walk down the trail at the top of the cliff.

content.description: Begin on the face below an overhanging (but easy) crack. Pull through the crack, and continue up the lichen face on positive features. Finish high on jugs with decent protection and great position.
content.protection: A standard rack, 0.1, 0.2 X4 came in handy for the last 10 feet, and camouflage tights.

content.description: This route climbs a slab line up the main face. It begins on a left-facing vertical rail and transitions to a right-facing vertical rail before making a move to a ledge. From there, climb through two juggy roofs to the top of the cliff.
content.location: Start about 10' to the left of the prominent finger crack line on the main face.

content.description: Climb an inside corner dihedral with some face/crack features. There is a funky exit. It may be loose up top.
content.protection: A light rack with single cams. . . up to a #5.
content.location: This is on the left (north) side of the main prow.

content.description:
Begin under the bush, climb the face to a large block sharing some features of

Jordan Can Climb It

. Pull the bulge, then climb the face angling left.
content.location:
It climbs the low angle face left of

Jordan Can Climb It

.

content.description: The route climbs a near-vertical face (between the off-width on the left and the dihedral on the right). The climbing consists of consistently good moves between flakes and crimps until the topout.
content.location: The climb is on the south-facing wall between the two crack routes.

content.description: This route begins with the obvious feature in the lower middle of the slab. Work your way straight up the face with thin hands and feet. The crux comes around the 3rd move from the bottom. After pulling the crux, grab ahold of an easy sloping ledge that leads to yet another short face. Head straight up the middle of the second face (5.7+), and avoid wandering left into the corner.
content.protection: TR only, it is easy to build an anchor on top.
content.location: Walk on top of the ridge heading north until the last 10-20 feet to set up the anchor. This is the route with the obvious, smooth, north-facing slab up top.

content.description: Begin below an adjustable flake, climb directly up to the roof, place some small gear, and pull through the roof on jugs to easier terrain.
content.location: It ascends the most obvious, plumb finger crack line on the main face, capped with a roof.
